title: 106_s2433
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Red River National Wildlife Refuge Act". The Red River Valley in Louisiana is crucial for over 350 bird species and other wildlife. The bottomland hardwood forests have been mostly cleared, but reforestation efforts can benefit many species. It serves as a migration corridor for birds traveling from the Arctic Circle to South America. The Red River Valley in Louisiana lacks public sanctuaries for over 300 river miles, but completion of the lock and dam system has improved fish and wildlife management opportunities. The area offers recreational and educational opportunities for various outdoor enthusiasts and is an internationally significant environmental resource in need of restoration and active management. The Red River Valley in Louisiana requires active restoration and management to protect its value as a habitat for fish and wildlife. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSES OF REFUGE. The Secretary will establish the Red River National Wildlife Refuge to preserve ecosystems, provide bird habitat, enhance fisheries, and manage native plants and animals. The Red River National Wildlife Refuge aims to preserve ecosystems, provide bird habitat, enhance fisheries, manage native plants and animals, offer technical assistance to private landowners, and provide recreational opportunities without violating regulations. The establishment of the Refuge will be published in the Federal Register and local publications. The administration of the refuge is outlined in Section 4. The Secretary administers lands, waters, and interests acquired under section 5 in accordance with the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966 and the Refuge Recreation Act. A management plan must be issued within 18 months, including provisions for planning trails and access points. The Secretary shall provide public participation in developing the management plan, giving special consideration to local views. Additionally, a Wildlife Interpretation and Education Center will be constructed within the Refuge. The Secretary will construct a wildlife interpretation and education center within the Refuge to promote environmental education and provide a space for studying and enjoying wildlife in its natural habitat. SEC. 5. ACQUISITION OF LANDS, WATERS, AND INTERESTS THEREIN. The Secretary aims to acquire up to 50,000 acres of land, water, or interests within designated boundaries for the Refuge through donation, exchange, or purchase from willing sellers. The boundaries will be designated in consultation with State and local officials, conservation organizations, and other interested parties. The Secretary plans to acquire land for the Red River National Wildlife Refuge within designated boundaries in consultation with various stakeholders. The boundaries will be designated to fulfill the purposes of the Refuge, and a detailed map will be prepared. The selection area includes Caddo, Bossier, Red River, and DeSoto. The Secretary may make minor boundary revisions for the Red River National Wildlife Refuge to achieve its purposes or facilitate property acquisition. The selection area includes Caddo, Bossier, Red River, DeSoto, and Natchitoches Parishes in Louisiana. The map will be available for public inspection and a notice will be published in the Federal Register. SEC. 6. CONTINUED PUBLIC SERVICES.

The Act does not prohibit the continuation of commercial or recreational navigation on the Red River Waterway, necessary construction activities, public port or recreational facilities development, or railroad and highway construction within the designated area.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funds are authorized for the Secretary to implement the Act.

SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The term "Refuge" refers to the Red River National Wildlife Refuge, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior.
